description: After the spring holidays on April 30th, it was announced that pupils of elementary schools in the Swiss canton of Lucerne are allowed to return to presence-based teaching on May 11th. Pupils of higher education (Gymnasium or high schools) return to presence-based teaching on June 8th. UPDATE: The original policy restricted present-based teaching until April 10, I am updating it to May 11, when first and second graders were allowed to return to school.

UPDATE: On 11th May compulsory schools in the Canton of Zug are due to reopen their doors to pupils and on 8th June attendance at secondary, vocational and technical colleges and universities will resume.

description: On 13th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel ordered the closure of all schools, professional training centers, high schools, universities, "hautes coles" (specialized higher education institutions) and extra-familial care centers (eg: day-care centers), from 16th March 2020 to 4th April 2020. A minimum extra-familial care service will be however provided on certain conditions to families who can't keep their children at home (conditions: parents work in healthcare, emergency or security services and have no other child care option).
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: Switzerland decided on national level to close all kindergartens as well as all private schools, schools for physically and mentally handicapped children, primary school and upper school (Primarschulen & Oberstufen) from the 16th of March to the 20th of April. The canton Aargau implements that policy and additionally also releases a policy only for the canton Aargau that the closed schools have to offer day care as long as the schools are closed from 08.00 a.m. to 12.00 p.m. and from 01:30 p.m. to 6 p.m.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: All schools in the canton Glarus moved to distance teaching, that means that teachers are giving homework and excercises to students while staying at home. Parents are advised to care for their youngest kids. When kids are supervised in groups, the care takers are advised to only care kid in small groups. The cantonal authorities announced this policy on March 22, 2020.

description:
On March 13th, 2020 the Swiss Federal council announces that all in person teaching at schools, universities and training centers are banned until April 4th. Exams that have already been scheduled can be carried out if certain protective measures are taken. However, the cantons can offer childcare for elementary schools to prevent children from being looked after by their grandparents.
This (Art. 5 Covid 19 ordinance 2) comes into force on March 16, 6 am.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 4, 2020 the Swiss Canton of Neuchatel Departement of Education announced the cancellation of all overnight - school trips and school skicamps starting next week ( March 9) till April 30. This policy was ended earlier because of federal school closure. UPDATE: Originally the cancellation of schooltrips was set to last till April 30, 2020, but was ended before because of federal school closure.

description: From March 16, the Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a closure of in-person lessons in all public and private obligatory and post-obligatory schools and universities. The lessons are announced to continue via yet unspecified online means. Exempt are children of essential workers during the pandemic, who will receive the same teaching activities. On April 17, the Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced the continuation of lessons in primary schools from May 11 and from June 8 in secondary and high schools, should the development of the virus allow it. UPDATE: On April 17, the Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced the continuation of lessons in primary schools from May 11 and from June 8 in secondary and high schools, shall the development of the virus allow it.

description: Following the Swiss federal announcement from March 13th, 2020, that schools must be closed, the canton of Appenzell Innerrhoden has announced that pupils in kindergarten, primary schools, and secondary schools can make use of school care hours. Students in the Gymnasium St. Antonius will continue studying via an online platform. Since May 11, all "Volksschulen" (elementary schools), and since June 8, the Gymnasium St. Antonius, have reintroduced presence-based teaching. UPDATE: Since May 11 (and June 8) all schools have introduced presence-based teaching.

Since May 11, all "Volksschulen" (elementary schools), and since June 8, the Gymnasium St. Antonius, have reintroduced presence-based teaching. UPDATE: Since May 11 (and June 8) all schools have introduced presence-based teaching.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: In accordance to a federal decision, the Swiss canton of St. Gallen requires schools at all levels to begin distance learning with no face-to-face meetings. Daycare centers will be required to still operate to accommodate parents who must work. This will be valid from March 16-April 19. UPDATE: The ban on face-to-face schooling has been pushed back from April 4 to April 19

description: Following the federal decision from April 29, 2020, to allow presence-based teaching from May 11 onwards, the Swiss canton of Appenzell Innerrhoden has decided to allow presence-based teaching in full class size from May 11 onwards. While primary and compulsory schools (age 4-15) open from May 11, secondary and high schools (Sek II) open on June 8 in full class size. All schools need to follow federal regulations on social distancing and hygiene. If classrooms can not guarantee a distance of two meters between each participant, rooms need to be changed.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
The authorities of the canton Schaffhausen announced on March 13th, 2020 that there will be no on-site teaching in the schools in the canton Schaffhausen, from March 16th onwards. There should be no on-site teaching until April 4th. The Schools should move to online teaching, the authorities said. 

Secondary schools and higher education institutions are allowed to go back to on-site teaching on June 8th, 2020.

institution_status: Primary Schools closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: All schools in the canton Glarus moved to distance teaching, that means that teachers are giving homework and excercises to students while staying at home. Parents are advised to care for their youngest kids. When kids are supervised in groups, the care takers are advised to only care kid in small groups. The cantonal authorities announced this policy on March 22, 2020. The communities of the canton have to provide free care for children in kindergartens and primary schools during usual class times during the day.

institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description:
On March 13, 2020 in Switzerland the State Council of Canton Valais announced the closure of all public and private schools, nurseries,  kindergartens, higher education institutions and vocational education institutions with immediate effect till April 30. Urgent childcare will be provided.
In addition to the already announced federal school closure starting March 16. UPDATE: On March 16 this policy was overruled by the Federal closure of schools, allowing cantons only to close childcare facilities if needed child care is provided.

institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description:
On 13th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel ordered the closure of all schools, professional training centers, high schools, universities, "hautes coles" (specialized higher education institutions) and extra-familial care centers (eg: day-care centers), from 16th March 2020 to 4th April 2020. A minimum extra-familial care service will be however provided on certain conditions to families who can't keep their children at home (conditions: parents work in healthcare or security and have no other child care option). On 16th March 2020, this policy was extended to 19th April 2020 by the federal Ordinance 2 of 16th March 2020, which took over all cantonal measures.
 UPDATE: The original closure of schools was set to last until 4th April 2020, but it has been extended to 19th April 2020.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Switzerland "At an extraordinary meeting today, 16 March 2020, the  Federal Council took the decision to introduce more stringent measures to protect the public".
"The new Ordinance on Measures to fight the Coronavirus also clarifies the question of child day-care facilities. The cantons are required to ensure that childcare is provided for children who cannot be looked after privately. Child day-care facilities may only be closed if other suitable arrangements exist. This measure will apply for the time being until 19 April. School closures will also now apply until this date."
This ordinance comes into force March 17.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)
link: NA ; https://www.admin.ch/opc/de/official-compilation/2020/783.pdf ; Ordinance ; 10-25-2020_Verordnung 2 ber Massnahmen zur Bekmpfung des Coronavirus nderung 16 Mrz

description: On march 19, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Grisons kindergartens, primary schools, special schools, day-care centers, crches and child-minders in the canton of Graubnden continue to look after children who cannot be looked after at home. The offer is aimed at parents who have no private opportunity to look after their children themselves or who would have them looked after by a person vulnerable to the virus.

description: On march 19, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Grisons kindergartens, primary schools, special schools, day-care centers, crches and child-minders in the canton of Graubnden continue to look after children who cannot be looked after at home. The offer is aimed at parents who have no private opportunity to look after their children themselves or who would have them looked after by a person vulnerable to the virus.

description: On March 18 2020, the Swiss canton Zurich announes, that from March 19 until April 30 the municipalities have to organize minimal care for children in nurseries, kindergardens and the primary stage of the elementary school. Private bodies can be obliged to run a day-care center. The offer is for people who urgently need care for their children or are working in system relevant jobs (health, care, safety, infrastructure, traffic, public administration, media, logistics).

description:
On March 23, in Switzerland the Canton Jura announced that
- all schools (compulsory and post-compulsory) will remain closed till April 30, 2020. 
- Admission to childcare facilities is limited to children who cannot benefit from a private daycare solution.
Priority is given to the children of people mobilized in the fight against the coronavirus, and for children whose placement is ordered or recommended by the authorities or social services. UPDATE: The original closure of schools and children daycare was  set to last till April 4, it has been extendet to April 30.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description: In Switzerland, the state council of the canton of Zurich decided at the 19th of march that the exams from the 25th of march will be moved to a later date because of the big numbers of candidates the health measures cant be met, thats why the oral exams and the creative aptitude tests will not take place.  This leads to adjustments of the admission procedure in middle schools and specialized middle school for the school year 2020/2021. For the admission, the result of the written examination will be decisive for pupils, according to the applicable admission regulations would have to take the oral exam. These pupils will be provisional accepted to the probationary period. The design aptitude tests for the K + S classes and the Liceo artisto will be exclusively based on the handed in documents of the candidates.
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On April 3, in Switzerland the Canton Jura announced an extended access to childcare facilities after April 6. 
In the absence of another private solution, parents working in the following areas can make requests: distribution of essential goods, bank, post office or even mobilization by civil protection or the army, provided that both spouses are active in these fields or that the request concerns a single-parent family .
 UPDATE: Originally all schools and childcare facilities were closed. Daycare was provided for children of medical and social staff. Now access to daycare is extended to children of parents working in essential business.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description:
On March 20 the Government Thurgau has announced, that Thurgau are following the decision of federal government and introduced the implementation phase with the duration from April 20 until Juli 3. 
It can be assumed that the COVID-19 regulation from 17.03.2020 will be extended and from April 20, 2020 regular lessons cannot be started. It is possible to define the framework conditions for the schools from this point on. UPDATE: The original implementation phase was set until July 3, it has been shortened until May 11 (the day in which school should be reopened for presence classes)

description:
On April 23, 2020 Swiss Canton Geneva has extended the closure of all private and public schools and children day care facilities ( age 4 to 14) till May 11. Minimum daycare is provided for children (age 4-10) of families without any other option.
Childcare facilities for small children ( age 0-4) will start to gradually reopen after April 27. A new directive for these institutions is launched.

 UPDATE: The original school closure was first set to last until April 9, then it has been extended till April 26, now it is extended till May 11, 2020.

description:
On April 30 Ticino announced the reopening of compulsory schools as of May 11. However non-compulsory schools, i.e. high schools for children from 15-18 and higher education institutes, remain closed. 
Elementary school (age 6-12) reopen part-time (minimum of 4 half days or 2 full days) and reduced in number of students (maximum half of a section of 25 students). This also applies to kindergarten ( age 4-6), but attendance will be voluntary. As before emergency childcare is provided, but not extended.
For secondary schools, the return to class occurs fractionally. Each institution taking into account the number of its students and its particularities (transport, canteen etc.), will organize one partial presence of the classes in place for at least one day (or two half-days per week). Distance learning will be extended.
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On April 30, 2020 the Department of Education in Swiss canton of Basel - City the announced that as of May 11, 2020, lessons for children will begin in kindergarten ( age 4-5), primary school (age 6-12) and lower secondary level ( age 12-15) according to the usual lesson times and the regular timetable in their classes.
According to the requirements of the Federal Office of Health (BAG), the distance rules between teachers  and students must be observed as far as possible.This is not necessary between the students themselves. Children day care facilities ( age 0 to 12) will open as well, but group size remains limited to 10 children. Remote learning will go on for post-obligatory education.

description:
On April 30, the Swiss canton of Obwalden announced that in accordance with federal guidelines, compulsory in-person education would resume with a hygiene concept on May 11. Restrictions include: Staff members must maintain social distancing (2m) from each other and students. Students from 5th grade and older are encouraged to practice social distancing outside the classroom, this does not apply to younger students. Hands must be washed upon entering school premises. Classrooms must be aired after every class, surfaces must be cleaned regularly. All school members are discouraged from sharing food, beverages, and dishes. All school members must be actively trained on these rules.

Written final exams take place normally, but without oral exams.

More tight restrictions apply to non-compulsory education, especially vocational training.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 1, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden specified its hygiene concept for the re-opening of compulsory schools permitted by the federal government beginning on May 11. The following measures are required: Hand washing is required upon entry to school premises and recommended when changing classrooms. Teachers must maintain social distancing whenever possible. School members with respiratory symptoms must not attend school. Gatherings of more than one class and sports with excessive body contact are discouraged. The use of separating plexiglass barriers is recommended.

description:
In Switzerland, the canton Aargau announces on April 24, 2020 that the written part of the Matura and final exams at secondary schools and at the Aargau Maturity School for adults will take place as planned as well as oral exams in some subjects at the technical secondary school.
On the other hand, the oral exams at the high school and at the Aargau maturity school for adults will not take place. At the technical middle school, oral exams are to be carried out in those subjects in which these are intended as the only examination form.

description:
On May 1, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Fribourg announced that the pupils of the 1st and 2nd cycle ( age 4 to 12) will return to the compulsory schools on May 11th in half-classes, two days per weeks. Group A on Mondays and Thursdays,  group B on Tuesdays and Fridays. till May 25th.
For students of secondary I schools distance learning will continue. Private secondary schools may open according to their own order. Emergency childcare for school children will continue. Secondary II schools ( age 16 - 18 ) may resume in groups of 5 students. The policy was announced to last until the summer holidays, starting on July 6. 

 UPDATE: The policy was announced to last until the beginning of the holidays in the Fribourg province, starting on July 6.

institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions

description: On 13th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel ordered the closure of all schools, professional training centers, high schools, universities, "hautes coles" (specialized higher education institutions) and extra-familial care centers (eg: day-care centers), from 16th March 2020 to 4th April 2020. A minimum extra-familial care service will be however provided on certain conditions to families who can't keep their children at home (conditions: parents work in healthcare or security and have no other child care option). On 16th March 2020, this policy was extended to 19th April 2020 by the federal Ordinance 2 of 16th March 2020, which took over all cantonal measures. On 30th April 2020, the canton of Neuchtel announced that in-person classes would resume in half-classes ("demi-classe") on 11th May 2020 for cycles 1 and 2 of compulsory schooling (1st to 8th year of education), thus ending the original policy.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
"At its meeting on April 29, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided to further ease the measures. From Monday, May 11 primary and lower secondary schools ( age 4 to 15) will be able to recommence classroom teaching. The FOPH and the Swiss Conference of Cantonal Directors of Education have drawn up requirements for the precautionary measures to be taken in consultation with the Science Taskforce and other experts. The cantons and communes have until 11 May to make arrangements for implementing these measures, taking account of local circumstances in each case. Schools will be allowed to be flexible in their approach to classroom teaching. Cantons to decide how classes will be taught. "
Covid 19 ordinance 2, Art. 5:  If there is no face-to-face teaching, the cantons will provide appropriate childcare for pupils. Children's day-care centers and other care offers must comply with the recommendations of the FOPH regarding hygiene and social distance.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

Emergency childcare for school children will continue.

Private secondary schools may open according to their own guidelines. Secondary II schools ( age 16 - 18 ) may resume in groups of 5 students. The original measures announced were supposed to last until the holidays, starting on July 6. 

 UPDATE: The original measures announced were supposed to last until the holidays, whereas no clear end date is indicated for an end to hygiene measures etc.

description:
On April 30, 2020 the State Council of Swiss Canton Vaud presented the measure taken by the cantonal Department of Education to reopen obligatory schools safely according to the framework guidelines of the Federal Office of Health and after having coordinated a return to class with the other French-speaking cantons.
Level 1P to 8P ( age 4 to 12) is scheduled to resume in full classes as of May 25.
In canton Vaud summer break started July 6, 2020.

description: On 28th May 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel announced that all post-compulsory schools (equivalent of high school) would resume in-person classes under conditions from 8th June 2020 on. Conditions are the following: people within schools have to keep a distance of 2 meters at least apart from one another; classes can be separated into different groups depending on the number of students per classes and the number of square meters in each classroom. Exceptions can be made for vulnerable students and teachers, who will have the possibility to continue online classes.

description:
On May 26, 2020 the Departement of Education of the Swiss canton of Vaud presented its protection plan for the return of around 37,000 students and apprentices from Secondary II schools to class on June 8th ( age 16 and over) till summer break ( starting July 6th).
The spatial distance of 2 meters must be maintained between the students and between students and teachers.
The lessons take place in small groups, depending on the size of the rooms in square meters (1 person per 4 square meters).
Students will therefore come to school alternately every other day or every third day or respectively one week out of 2 or 3 for apprentices.
Homework is given for days without lessons. Only past year students who already received their title will not be required to return to class.

description:
On May 28, 2020 the Swiss Canton of Basel City announced that after the compulsory school (age 4-15) started classroom teaching on May 11, 2020, lessons will also start again at the vocational and upper secondary schools (age 15-18) from June 8, 2020. Social distancing (2m) must be maintained in the classroom. Depending on the spatial situation - there are different teaching models until summer break (June 26). At certain schools practically all students can attend face-to-face lessons, at others there is a mixture of face-to-face and distance learning.
Group size in childcare facilities is no longer restricted due to corona and school trips can resume as well.

description:
At its meeting on May 27, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided that  the measures put in place to fight the new coronavirus will be extensively eased. Classroom teaching at upper secondary ( age 16 and above) and at vocational schools and at higher education institutions will be allowed to resume from June 8th. 
Under what form the teaching resumes is a matter for the cantons or the educational institutions.Teaching can be organised flexibly and distance-learning can still be used. All educational institutions must develop and implement a protection concept.The responsible cantonal authorities ensure that the relevant requirements are implemented within the framework protection concepts established by the FOPH.
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 30 April, the canton of Bern, Switzerland, announces the reopening of classrooms for middle and highschool students as well as vocational schools beginning on 8 June. Schools will reopen for half-time for two days, to begin. Students and faculty are set to follow hygiene precautions, social distancing measures. UPDATE: Originally, the middle schools and vocational schools and other secondary schools were supposed to reopen under a "mixed" policy as of June 8th. However, announced May 14th, there will be no face to face instruction for most students. Face to face instruction will only occur for those in need or with difficulty to the new format.

description:
On 30th April 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel announced its plan for the reopening of classes (for compulsory school, see records 8429061 and 1859975) but all post-compulsory schools (equivalent of high school) remain closed until further notice. Universities are to remain closed as well due to the absence of announcements regarding the resumption of classes. On 28th May 2020, the canton announced that in-person classes would resume under conditions in post-compulsory schools on 8th June 2020, thus ending this policy.

NB: there was no information on resumption of classes for universities, but one can consider the closure of universities ended as well because most (if not all) university calendars end in late May. UPDATE: The original closure of post-compulsory schools and universities didn't have an end date, but on 28th May 2020, the canton of Neuchtel announced that in-person classes would resume under conditions in post-compulsory schools on 8th June 2020, thus ending this policy.
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools closed/locked down

description: On May 28th, the the government of the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that higher educational facilities (secondary level II), including vocational schools, would reopen on June 8th while adhering hygiene concepts. This includes permanent social distancing of 2m and the general calculation of 4 square metres per student in the classroms. Tele-teaching would still be offered, if needed. This policy effectively ended on August 9th with the introduction of a more comprehensive policy on the following day. UPDATE: The original policy was open-ended. This however, changed with the introduction of a new and more comprehensive policy, starting on August 10th which e.g. changed the social distance from 2 to 1.5m.

description: On 28th May 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel announced that all post-compulsory schools (equivalent of high school) would resume in-person classes under conditions from 8th June 2020 on. Conditions are the following: people within schools have to keep a distance of 2 meters at least apart from one another; classes can be separated into different groups depending on the number of students per classes and the number of square meters in each classroom. Exceptions can be made for vulnerable students and teachers, who will have the possibility to continue online classes. The academic year ended on 6th July 2020 at the start of the summer break, thus ending this policy. UPDATE: The original policy had no end date, but the academic year ended on 6th July 2020 at the start of the summer break. This automatically ended the policy.

description:
On August 18th 2020, the Swiss Canton of Vaud announced that it would start and resume school for the next school year under revised policies including but not limited to social distancing measures and population density as well as online learning.

Health protection plans have been drawn up around several scenarios that can be activated depending on the epidemiological evolution. The current situation allows for a resumption of classes starting on the 24th of August 2020. wearing a mask is becoming the new rule for all teachers, except during classroom time if they can maintain a distance of 1.5 meters. Wearing a mask also applies during lessons for post-compulsory students, as well as throughout the school perimeter.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description: On August 10, the Swiss Canton Ticino, announces the new measures for the re-opening of schools on August 31. In general, schools are foreseen to reopen with face to face classes. Masks will be optional for middle and post-compulsory students, for teachers, it will be optional during lessons and mandatory in the common areas. The common measures of hygiene and social distancing apply. In compulsory school, the distance of 1.5 meters between students is not indicated as necessary. The distance between the teacher and the students and between the adults present is important. In the post-compulsory school, where children are considered as adults, the distance must also be maintained between students. As for some disciplines such as physical education, there will be specific indications to avoid sports that involve frequent direct physical contact between students.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description: The goverment of the Swiss Canton Grisons announced on October 16, 2020 in all secondary schools II/2 (age 16 and older) masks will be mandatory for all persons on the school ground. Only in class rooms the masks can be taken off, if there is enough distance (1,5meters) between each person or physical barriers like plexiglass. If not, masks are mandatory for  teachers in class rooms. In all other schools masks will be mandatory for all adults. Exceptions are only possible for special need schools after consultation with the Cantonal doctor. This measure takes effect starting October 17, 2020.

description: The education department of the Swiss Cantion Saint Gallen announced on October 30, 2020 that masks will be mandatory in high schools ("Oberstufe", age 16-18) starting from November 2,2020. In other schools masks are already mandatory, but there it was ordered by the federal government. The masks will be mandatory on the whole school ground and during classes. Also singing should be avoided. While so called contact sports like soccer or basketball are already prohibited by the federal government, the provincial education department now also orders that the physical education classes must be cut in half if it does not take place outside with social distancing measures. If a student had contact to a positive-tested person and couldn't keep the minimum distance or wear a mask he is also under quarantine.

description:
On March 13 the Government  councilor of Canton Thurgau has announced state of an exceptional situation (Auergewhnliche Lage). 
In doing so, it hands over further competencies in the organizational and financial area to the management team (Fhrungsstab). The extraordinary situation in the canton of Thurgau currently has no further consequences for the population.

description: On March 15, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Basel-Landschaft has declared the State of Emergency.
On March 16,2020 in Switzerland Canton Valais declares an 'extraordinary situation' (aussergewhliche Situation).
On March 16, 2020 in Switzerland the council of Canton Vaud declares a situation of necessity within the territory of Canton Vaud according to Swiss Epidemics Act.
On March 16, 2020 the State Council of Swiss Canton of Geneva declares the state of emergency  (l'tat de ncessit).

In Switzerland, the canton Aargau declares at the 16th or March the state of emergency. This includes the ban of public and private events, closed shops, markets, restaurants, bars, museums, leisure facilities, libraries, cinemas, theatres, concert halls, gyms and swimming halls as well as shops where people cant keep enough distance like hairdressers and make up studios. Supermarkets, take-aways, company canteens, delivery services for food, pharmacies, gas stations, train stations, banks, post offices, hotels, car repair shops, public administration and social facilities will stay open will stay open as long as they fulfil the distance and hygiene regulations. Hospitals, clinics and doctors surgeries will stay open but not preform not urgent treatment. People with high risk of getting infected will be on payed leave. Day cares will only be closed if other appropriate care exists.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 16th, The Swiss Federal Council announces an "extraordinary situation" [ausserordentliche Lage] within their epidemic legislative procedure.

On Monday, March 16, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Uri held an extraordinary meeting  and decided on immediate measures in connection with protection against the coronavirus. It has determined the extraordinary situation for the entire canton of Uri in accordance with Article 2 of the Law on Civil Protection in the canton of Uri.
(announced March 17)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On 18th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel declared an "extraordinary situation" in the canton, which gave extraordinary powers to the State council in order to protect the population.

NB: This decision echoes and refers to the declaration of "extraordinary situation" by the Swiss federal government on 16th March 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
on March 27, 2020 the Swiss federal council defines a new regional limited situation of 'special threat' (besondere Gefhrdungslage) and issues an order ( refering to the Swiss Epidemics Act) to allow single cantons to take further measures on economic sectors in coordination with the federal council to fight the epidemie. This will apply backward after March 21,2020: ( to backward legalize Ticino policies).

 UPDATE: Originally Declaration of special situation, then declaration of extraordinary situation, now Definition and Application of a regional limited special situation of threat

On March 27, 2020 in Switzerland the State Council of Canton Ticino extended the State of Emergency for the entire territory of Ticino till April 19, 2020. UPDATE: The original state of emergency is now limited till April 19.

On April 15, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Ticino extended the State of Emergency for the entire territory of Ticino till May 31, 2020. UPDATE: The original state of emergency is now limited till May 31, 2020.

On 18th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel declared an "extraordinary situation" in the canton, which gave extraordinary powers to the State council in order to protect the population.
NB: This decision echoes and refers to the declaration of "extraordinary situation" by the Swiss federal government on 16th March 2020.
 
On 5th May 2020, the Grand Council of the Canton of Neuchtel reaffirmed the "extraordinary situation" and extended it to 26th May 2020. UPDATE: The original declaration of emergency had no end date, but on 5th May 2020, the Grand Council of Neuchtel reaffirmed the "extraordinary situation" and extended it to 26th May 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On May 20 the Swiss Canton Ticino extended the state of emergency for the entire territory of Ticino to June 30. 

 UPDATE: Ticino declared the state of emergency on March 11, it was then extended a first time to April 19 and then a second time to May 31. On May 20 it has been extended again to June 30

On May 26, 2020 Swiss Canton Basel-Landschaft announced that as of May 31, 2020, midnight, the government council is lifting the State of Emergency for the Canton of Basel-Landschaft.
 UPDATE: The original declaration of state of emergency was open ended, it has been ended May 31.

On June 4, 2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Jura announced the end of the State of Emergency (tat de ncessit) as of June 6, 2020. UPDATE: The State of Emergency was declared without ending, now it is ended as of June 6, 2020.

On Monday, March 16, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Uri held an extraordinary meeting  and decided on immediate measures in connection with protection against the coronavirus. It has determined the extraordinary situation for the entire canton of Uri in accordance with Article 2 of the Law on Civil Protection in the canton of Uri.
(announced March 17) UPDATE: On June 9th, 2020  the government council of Swiss canton Uri announced: Since March 16, 2020, the extraordinary situation in accordance with the cantonal civil protection law has applied in the canton of Uri due to the rapid spread of the coronavirus.In the canton of Uri there have been no new infections for weeks. As a result, the government council decided to return to normal in the canton of Uri on Friday, June 12, 2020
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: Since the 9th of March 2020, the Swiss border controls (EZV) set up a monitoring system to oversee the effectiveness of the Italian measures. The border control (EZV) uses intensified sampling and checks that are carried out on a risk basis at the land border to Italy. An example of such measures would be the checking of passports and work permits.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 11, Ticino closes 9 minor mountain passes on the Italian border, i.e. Pedrinate, Ponte Faloppia, Novazzano Marcetto, San Pietro di Stabio, Ligornetto Cantinetta, Arzo, Ponte Cremenaga, Cassinone, Indemini.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
The swiss federal council decided that from the 11th of March 2020 on Switzerland cross-border travelling from Italy to Switzerland will be limited to only a few borders crossings. The small border crossings will be closed and the border traffic will be channeled to the big border crossings. 

Following the closed border crossings -> alternative open border crossings

Pedrinate -> Chiasso strada (Ponte Chiasso)
Ponte Faloppia -> Novazzano Brusata (Bizzarone) or Chiasso strada
Novazzano Marcetto -> Novazzano Brusata (Bizzarone) or Chiasso strada
San Pietro di Stabio -> Stabio Gaggiolo
Ligornetto Cantinetta -> Stabio Gaggiolo
Arzo -> Stabio Gaggiolo or Brusino Arsizio
Ponte Cremenaga -> Fornasette or Ponte Tresa
Cassinone -> Fornasette
Indemini -> Dirinella (Zenna)
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: All external Swiss borders, including mountain passes in Ticino reopen on June 15 to Schengen members and the UK. This is in line with the federal decision. UPDATE: All Swiss external borders, including mountain passes in Ticino, open on June 15 to Schengen members and the UK.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 13th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council re-opens federal border checks including Schengen checks at the Italian border designed to limit incoming traffic from Italy to Switzerland. Only Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, people who only travel through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons are allowed to enter from Italy. Transit and goods traffic are still allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from Italy.
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Only Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons are allowed to enter Italy. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from Italy.

description: Since the 9th of March 2020, the swiss border controls set up a monitoring system to monitor the effectiveness of the Italian measures. description: On March 16, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council announced its intention to mobilize up to a maximum of 8,000 military personnel to support the civil health service, the Federal Customs Administration and the cantonal police forces. This support includes medical services, logistical tasks such as transportation and assistance in building improvisational infrastructure, and protection assistance at national borders and airports.

description: On March 11, Ticino closes 9 minor mountain passes on the Italian border, i.e. Pedrinate, Ponte Faloppia, Novazzano Marcetto, San Pietro di Stabio, Ligornetto Cantinetta, Arzo, Ponte Cremenaga, Cassinone, Indemini. On March 16 5 other minor mountain passes were added to the temporary closure, namely Arogno, Brusino, Pizzamiglio, Camedo e Fornasette. UPDATE: Additional to the already closed 9 mountain passes on March 11, as of March 16 five other minor mountain passes are closed, i.e. Arogno, Brusino, Pizzamiglio, Camedo e Fornasette.

description: From the 17 March 2020 onwards, the Swiss Federal Council extends the entrance ban introduced to Italy to France, Austria and Germany. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from these countries.

description: On March 17th 2020 the Swiss Federal Council (Schweizer Bundesrat) Closed additional to the already closed Italian border also the borders to Germany, France and Austria. Only Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons are allowed to enter Italy. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter. UPDATE: Originally the swiss border that was closed was only the border to Italy but now it is also the the borders to Germany, France and Austria
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 13th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council re-opens federal border checks including Schengen checks at the Italian border designed to limit incoming traffic from Italy to Switzerland. Only Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, people who only travel through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons are allowed to enter from Italy. Transit and goods traffic are still allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from Italy. UPDATE: The original geographical target for this external border restriction was Italy. Since March 17th, this policy has been expanded to Austria, France and Germany.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, the Federal Council declares that the issuance and authorization of Schengen as well as national visas from Germany, France, Italy, Austria, Spain and all non-Schengen states is discontinued. This does not apply to applications from people in a situation of extreme necessity or from specialists in the health sector.
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)

description: On March 18, the Swiss Federal Council extends the entrance ban introduced to Germany, Austria, Italy and France to foreign travelers from Spain and all non-Schengen states. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons as well as supporting health care workers. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from these countries.

description: From March 19, 2020 0:00 JST "until further notice, entry to Japan will be denied to foreigners who have visited" the Canton of Ticino and the Canton of Basel-City  (Switzerland) "within 14 days prior to the application for landing", in accordance with Article 5, Paragraph (1), Item (xiv) of the Immigration Control and Refugee Recognition Act, "unless exceptional circumstances are found". "Japanese nationals are exempted."
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)

description:
In Switzerland the swiss federal council decided that from the 19th of march on additionalyl to the countries from where citizens are already not allowed to travel to Switzerland (Italy, Germany, Austria, France) also citizens from Spain and all non EU/ EFTA are not allowed to enter Switzerland anymore besides with a few exceptions. 
Also the swiss federal state decided that additional to the already existing exceptions of why people would be allowed to enter Switzerland also necessary health workers will be allowed to enter. UPDATE: Additional to the countries from where citizens are not allowed to travel to Switzerland anymore also citizens from Spain and all non EU/ EFTA are not allowed to enter Switzerland anymore besides with a few exceptions. 
Also the Bundesrat state that additional to the already existing exceptions also necessary health workers will be allowed to enter Switzerland
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: In Switzerland the swiss federal council stated that additional to the originally people that were banned from entering from Italy, Germany, France and Austria from the 19th of March on also people from Spain and non EU/ EFTA countries are banned from entering Switzerland. Additional to that, the exceptions of why a person is allowed to enter Switzerland got upgraded to another one that says that also necessary health workers are allowed to enter. UPDATE: Originally people were banned from entering from Italy, Germany, France and Austria but now also people from Spain and non EU/ EFTA countries are banned from entering Switzerland. Additional to that the exceptions of why a person is allowed to enter Switzerland got upgraded to another one that says that also necessary health workers are allowed to enter.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On the 21st of March the swiss federal council changed the frontier crossing ban. Instead of forbidding people from Spain, Germany, Austria, Italy and all countries that are not an EU/ EFTA country to enter it changed to people from Spain, Germany, Austria and Italy and countries that are not part of the Schengen agreement are not allowed to enter. UPDATE: On the 21st of March the frontier crossing ban got changed.Instead of forbidding people from Spain, Germany, Austria, Italy and all countries that are not an EU/ EFTA country to enter the policy changed so people from Spain, Germany, Austria and Italy and countries that are not part of the Schengen agreement are not allowed to enter Switzerland.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On the 21st of March the frontier crossing ban got changed. description:
Switzerland, Geneva--Beginning March 22 at 6 a.m. the canton will only have 8 open custom ports. 

"4 will be open 24 hours, each with a priority lane for badge holders: Anires
Bardonnex
Ferney-Voltaire
Thnex-Vallard

3 will be open for 24 hours without a priority lane: 
Moillesulaz
Perly
Meyrin

2 will only be open from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m.:
Mon-Ide
Veyrier"

"Les quatre douanes suivantes seront ouvertes 24 heures sur 24 et compteront chacune une voie prioritaire rserve aux dtenteurs d'un macaron:
Anires
Bardonnex
Ferney-Voltaire
Thnex-Vallard
Les trois douanes suivantes seront ouvertes 24 heures sur 24 sans voie prioritaire:
Moillesulaz
Perly
Meyrin
Deux autres douanes seront ouvertes de 6 heures  20 heures:
Mon-Ide
Veyrier"
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction

description: In Switzerland the swiss federal council decided to change the entry restrictions. At the 25th of March 2020 the policy got implemented that not like before only flights from Italy, Germany, France and Austria will be channeled to the airpots Zrich-Kloten, Genf-Cointrin und Basel-Mulhouse but that all international flights will be now channeled to these airports UPDATE: In Switzerland the swiss federal council decided to change the entry restrictions. At the 25th of March 2020 the policy got implemented that not like before only flights from Italy, Germany, France and Austria will be channeled to the airpots Zrich-Kloten, Genf-Cointrin und Basel-Mulhouse but that all international flights will be now channeled to these airports
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction

description:
In Switzerland, additional to the channelling of the border traffic from Italy the swiss federal council decided that from the 19th of march on also flights will be included in these restrictions and that also other countries like Germany, Austria, Spain and France will be included into the channeling of border traffic.

Flights from these countries will be channeled to the airports: Zrich-Kloten, Genf-Cointrin und Basel-Mulhouse. 

Also the EJPD is from the 19th of march on allowed to decide about restrictions in road traffic, traffic by ship, airplanes, trains can after consulting with the EDI, the UVEK, the EDI and the EDA 
The EJPD can also channel movement of travellers to certain border crossings, airports, harbours
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: In Switzerland at the 2nd of April the swiss federal council implemented that people that enter Switzerland without being allowed to enter because of certain exceptions have to pay a fine of 100CHF UPDATE: At the 2nd of April the swiss federal council implemented that people that enter Switzerland without being allowed to enter because of certain exceptions have to pay a fine of 100CHF
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
In Switzerland the swiss federal council decided that from the 2nd of April 2020 on customs (Die Eidgenssische Zollverwaltung (EZV)) is allowed to close small border crossings independently if needed. The closure will be immediately reported to the EJPD, UVEK and the EDA. Costumes will mark closed borders and publishes based in this data a list of open borders on their website.

Also from the 2nd of April 2020 on customs will decide which streets for prior traffic (green lanes) will be kept to keep the flow of essential goods up that the state supply can be maintained. The same applies to essential workers, especially people working in health care. Customs will publish the list of the green lanes and which conditions are necessary to use them on their website

The swiss federal council decided that from the 2nd of April on the entry with a cross-border commuter permit (Grenzgngerbewilligung) based on passage 1 letter b to Switzerland is only permitted for occupational reasons.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: From April 17 onwards, the Swiss federal council is putting a fine of CHF 100 on border crossings of Swiss residents for shopping tourism in France, Italy, Liechtenstein, Austria, and Germany to prevent the obstruction of the work of the border control authority.

description:
In Switzerland the swiss federal council decided that from the 17th April 2020 on the State Secretariat for Migration passes the necessary instructions to judge who has legitimate reasons to enter Switzerland. 

Also from the 17th of April on it is forbidden to import goods from all neighbouring countries besides Liechtenstein if the reason for travelling to a neighbouring country was in the first place to buy and then import goods to Switzerland UPDATE: From the 17 April 2020 on the State Secretariat for Migration passes the necessary instructions to judge who has legitimate reasons to enter Switzerland. Before that the border control had to judge if somebody has legitimate reasons to enter Switzerland 

Also from the 17th of April on it is forbidden to import goods from all neighbouring countries besides Liechtenstein if the reason for travelling to a neighbouring country was in the first place to buy and then import goods to Switzerland
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The Swiss Federal Council will relax border restrictions set to last until April 26th  for those who submitted work/visa applications before March 25th, including cross-border commuters. Other border controls will remain in place. Decided on April 26th UPDATE: The border restrictions set to last until April 26th will be relaxed for those who submitted work/visa applications before March 25th, including cross-border commuters. Other border controls will remain in place

description: On May 11, the Swiss Federal Council relaxes the external border checks introduced to foreign travelers from all states except for Liechtenstein for foreign workers, family reunifications and students from France. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, family reunifications, students from France, people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons as well as supporting health care workers. Foreign workers who applied for short-term employment and whose professional activity is necessary for the national well-being are allowed to enter Switzerland if either their application was submitted to the responsible cantonal authority before the border restrictions enacted on 25 March 2020 (European or EFTA states) or their application was approved prior to March 19 2020 but the border crossing was impossible because of the restriction on the approval of Visa or residence permits (non European/EFTA states). Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter.
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban

description:
In Switzerland the swiss federal council decided that from the 11th of march on that:
Immigrants that are not covered by the FZA or the agreement from the 4th of January 1960 about the formation of the EFTA-agreement do have to fulfil the additional entry fulfilments.
The responsible authorities are allowed to do risk-based controls 
Permission for immigrants that are entitled to free movement. Immigrants that are covered by the FZA or the EFTA, want to work in Switzerland for a short time are allowed to enter if:
-If the permit is in the interest of the public, especially in economic state supply 
-For family reunification 
-If the request for employment got handed in at the correct cantonal office before the 25th of march 2020 or if there was already a contract of employment with a swiss company 
-If the request for short term cross-border service is in line with the notification procedure and the service agreement was signed before the 25th of march 2020 
Immigrants that are not covered by the FZA and EFTA agreement are allowed to enter Switzerland if:
-They are in a situation of necessity or if they are health workers
-they got an entry permit before the 19th or march 2020 but the entry permit, visa, or a  residence permit that couldnt get certificated because of the current COVID-19 measures
-if the request of the employer got handed in before the 19th of march 2020. 
the migration of family members of swiss citizens based on article 42 AIG3 UPDATE: The swiss federal council published new laws for the entry permission
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 25, the Federal Council declares that the issuance and authorization of Schengen as well as national visas from all states except for Liechtenstein is discontinued. This does not apply to applications from people in a situation of extreme necessity or from specialists in the health sector.

description: On March 25, the Swiss Federal Council extends the external border checks introduced to Germany, Austria, Italy, France, Spain and all non-Schengen states to foreign travelers from all Schengen states except for Liechtenstein and all other states. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons as well as supporting health care workers. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from these countries. On May 11, this restriction was relaxed for foreign workers, family reunifications, and students from Italy.

description: In an agreement of May 15, 2020 with Germany and Austria, the Swiss Federal Department of Justice and Police allows people who wish to visit their partners or relatives or participate in important family events to cross the Swiss border using a self-declaration form. The same applies to owners of properties and gardens used by themselves as well as of agricultural, hunting or forestry land. Persons who have to care for animals may also enter.

description: On March 28th of May 2020, the Swiss Federal Council re-opens the federal border to the Schengen countries (the border to Liechtenstein was never closed). All other countries besides the Schengen countries are still prohibited to enter Switzerland. UPDATE: On the 28th of May Switzerland opened its borders again to certain countries
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: Since June 3, the Federal Department of the Interior (EDI) may, after consultation with the Federal Department of Justice and Police (EJPD) and the Federal Department of Finance (EFD), impose border sanitation measures, such as temperature measurements, health questionnaires or quarantine measures, on people who intend to enter Switzerland from a risk country or region.

description: On June 8, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council relaxes the external border checks introduced to foreign travelers from all states except for Liechtenstein for partners of Swiss residents and foreigners in education and training. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, family reunifications, partners of Swiss residents (e.g. to prepare for marriage), students from France, people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons such as foreigns attending education and training >90 days as well as supporting health care workers. Foreign workers who applied for short-term employment and whose professional activity is necessary for the national well-being are allowed to enter Switzerland if either their application was submitted to the responsible cantonal authority before the border restrictions enacted on 25 March 2020 (European or EFTA states) or their application was approved prior to March 19 2020 but the border crossing was impossible because of the restriction on the approval of Visa or residence permits (non European/EFTA states). Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter.

description: On May 11, the Swiss Federal Council relaxes the external border checks introduced to foreign travelers from all states except for Liechtenstein for foreign workers, family reunifications and students from France. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, family reunifications, students from France, people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons as well as supporting health care workers. Foreign workers who applied for short-term employment and whose professional activity is necessary for the national well-being are allowed to enter Switzerland if either their application was submitted to the responsible cantonal authority before the border restrictions enacted on 25 March 2020 (European or EFTA states) or their application was approved prior to March 19 2020 but the border crossing was impossible because of the restriction on the approval of Visa or residence permits (non European/EFTA states). Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter. UPDATE: The external border restrictions were further relaxed on June 8, 2020 for partners of Swiss residents and foreigners who attend education and training measures of over 90 days.
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban

description: On June 15, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council reopens the Swiss border to all Schengen states. External border checks remain in place for all states outside the Schengen agreement. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, family reunifications, partners of Swiss residents (e.g. to prepare for marriage), people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons such as foreigns attending education and training >90 days as well as supporting health care workers. Foreign workers from non European/EFTA states who applied for short-term employment and whose professional activity is necessary for the national well-being are allowed to enter Switzerland if their application was approved prior to March 19, 2020 but the border crossing was impossible because of the restriction on the approval of Visas. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter.
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban

description: The Swiss federal council has announced plans to re-open the borders between France, Austria and Germany on June 15th should the epidemiological allow it after a bilateral agreement on May 13th 2020. UPDATE: The external border restrictions currently in place on the border between Switzerland, France, Austria and Germany will be lifted on June 15th 2020 should the epidemiological allow it, after a bilateral agreement on May 13th 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In an agreement of May 15, 2020 with Germany and Austria, the Swiss Federal Department of Justice and Police allows people who wish to visit their partners or relatives or participate in important family events to cross the Swiss border using a self-declaration form. The same applies to owners of properties and gardens used by themselves as well as of agricultural, hunting or forestry land. Persons who have to care for animals may also enter. UPDATE: The agreement of May 15, 2020 between Switzerland, Austria and Germany for partners, relatives and property owners is no longer in force since Switzerland has reopened the borders to Schengen states on June 15, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From April 17 onwards, the Swiss federal council is putting a fine of CHF 100 on border crossings of Swiss residents for shopping tourism in France, Italy, Liechtenstein, Austria, and Germany to prevent the obstruction of the work of the border control authority. UPDATE: With the re-opening of Schengen and Efta states' borders on June 15, 2020, shopping tourism is allowed again.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since June 3, the Federal Department of the Interior (EDI) may, after consultation with the Federal Department of Justice and Police (EJPD) and the Federal Department of Finance (EFD), impose border sanitation measures, such as temperature measurements, health questionnaires or quarantine measures, on people who intend to enter Switzerland from a risk country or region. UPDATE: The border sanitation measures introduced on June 3 to people entering Switzerland from a risk country/region no longer apply to Schengen states since June 15.
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)

description:
On July 1st, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided that from July 6th on all persons who enter Switzerland and who have been in a high risk Sars-CoV-2 country/ area within the last 14 days have to quarantine for 10 days (at home or in another appropiate accommodation). They have to report themselves within 2 days to the responsible cantonal authorities.Persons who have to go into quarantine are not entitled to loss of earnings compensation. Non - compliance can be fined.
Excepted are persons 
a. who professionally transport people or goods across borders
b. whose activity is absolutely necessary for maintaining the functionality of the health system or public security or international institutions
c. who have stayed in a risk country in the course of their professional activity in companies involved in rail, bus, ship or air transport 
d. who have to travel to Switzerland daily or up to 5 days for occupational or medical necessities
e. who have been less than 24h in a risk country (transit passengers)
f. who just pass through Switzerland.
The FOPH has a list of the countries concerned, which it updates regularly: Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Belarus, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Dominican republic, Honduras, Iraq, Israel, Cabo Verde, Qatar, Colombia, Kosovo, Kuwait, Moldova, North Macedonia, Oman, Panama, Peru, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Sweden, Serbia, South Africa, Turks- and Caicos islands (UK), USA
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On July 6, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council maintains the external border checks for foreigners from outside the Schengen agreement. Foreign nationals without an employment permit of at least 90 days in Switzerland will be refused entry. Entrance remains allowed for people in a situation of absolute necessity. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed.

description: On 6 July 2020, the Swiss Federal Council ensures that foreigners who have been prevented from taking action to grant family reunifications or residence permits in due time due to measures related to the coronavirus may make up for missed deadlines without negative consequences. This also applies to the deadlines for the renewal of biometric data for the issuance or extension of a permit.
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_what: Foreign Residents (Foreign Nationals Residing in the Country)

description:
On July 1st, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided that from July 6th on all persons who enter Switzerland and who have been in a high risk Sars-CoV-2 country/ area within the last 14 days have to quarantine for 10 days (at home or in another appropiate accommodation). They have to report themselves within 2 days to the responsible cantonal authorities.Persons who have to go into quarantine are not entitled to loss of earnings compensation. Non - compliance can be fined.
Excepted are persons 
a. who professionally transport people or goods across borders
b. whose activity is absolutely necessary for maintaining the functionality of the health system or public security or international institutions
c. who have stayed in a risk country in the course of their professional activity in companies involved in rail, bus, ship or air transport 
d. who have to travel to Switzerland daily or up to 5 days for occupational or medical necessities
e. who have been less than 24h in a risk country (transit passengers)
f. who just pass through Switzerland.
The FOPH has a list of the countries concerned, which it updates regularly: Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Belarus, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Dominican republic, Honduras, Iraq, Israel, Cabo Verde, Qatar, Colombia, Kosovo, Kuwait, Moldova, North Macedonia, Oman, Panama, Peru, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Sweden, Serbia, South Africa, Turks- and Caicos islands (UK), USA
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On June 15, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council reopens the Swiss border to all Schengen states. External border checks remain in place for all states outside the Schengen agreement. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, family reunifications, partners of Swiss residents (e.g. to prepare for marriage), people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons such as foreigns attending education and training >90 days as well as supporting health care workers. Foreign workers from non European/EFTA states who applied for short-term employment and whose professional activity is necessary for the national well-being are allowed to enter Switzerland if their application was approved prior to March 19, 2020 but the border crossing was impossible because of the restriction on the approval of Visas. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter. UPDATE: The external border restrictions in place for all states outside the Schengen agreement as of June 15, 2020 are relaxed for all foreign workers from non-European/EFTA states on July, 6, 2020.

description: On July 20, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council maintains the external border checks for foreigners from countries outside the Schengen agreement except for Algeria, Andorra, Australia, Bulgaria, Canada, Croatia, Cyprus, Ireland, Japan, Morocco, Monaco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Romania, San Marino, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, Georgia and Vatican City. Foreign nationals from risk countries without an employment permit of at least 90 days in Switzerland will be refused entry. Entrance remains allowed for people in a situation of absolute necessity. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed.

description:
The list of considered risk countries was updated on August 20, 2020 by the Swiss FOPH. As before all persons entering Switzerland coming from a risk country have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. Quarantined persons do not get loss of earnings compensation, but exempted they could not know in advance that their travel destination will be a risk area. They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Exempted are transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions.
on the list of risk countries as of August 20th: Spain including Balearic Islands and except Canary Islands UPDATE: With the update of the list of risk countries as of September 14,2020, Canaric Island were no longer excepted, but whole Spain was considered a risk country.

description:
On Sept 11, the Swiss Federal Council decided on the new list of risk countries as of Sept.14. All persons entering Switzerland having stayed in a risk country within the last 10 ! days have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the quarantine requirement. There is no loss of earnings compensation (except change of list after departure). Travelers have to report to the cantonal authorities that can adjust the duration of the quarantine and carry out spot checks. Starting Sept.14  professionals re-entering after participating in an event like sports competition or cultural event or a specialist congress are exempted and as before diplomats, transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions.
