description:
On March 20th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced the reduction of certain administrative functions until further notice. The concerned functions are the following: 
i) Any proceeding that requires a consultation session to be held are being suspended;

ii) For proceedings before special instances of the administrative jurisdiction (as defined by Article 4, clause 2 of the Code of Administrative Proceedings) and before administrative authorities as per Article 3 of the Code of Administrative Proceedings, any notification of decision which is subject to opposition, response or recourse are being held back until 30th April 2020. 

iii) Treatment of demands for popular communal cantonal initiatives, communal initiatives, popular initiatives and optional referenda for communal and cantonal purposes are suspended.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On March 20, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Coucil announced that the following statutory deadlines stand still as of March 21 till may 31:
- Deadline for submitting signature lists for a popular initiative 
- Deadline for the treatment of popular initiatives
- Deadline for the submission of a popular initiative 
The following actions are not carried out during the standstill.
- Disposal of the creation of referenda
- Popular vote on a federal referendum
The collection of signatures is prohibited.

description:
On March 19, 2020 in Switzerland the canton of Basel-Landschaft announced that the cantonal police force is temporarily concentrating its post operations at a number of central locations
As of Monday, March 23, 2020 the Allschwil, Therwil, Pratteln, Sissach and Waldenburg sites will be temporarily closed.
The major sites in Liestal, Reinach, Binningen, Muttenz and Laufen remain open.
The provision of police services to the population is fully guaranteed.
On June 24 the reopening as of June 29 was announced.

description:
On 15th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel ordered the closure of all public places providing recreational services, including public museums and public swimming-pools, until 30th April 2020. On 23rd March 2020, the Canton abrogated the order which comprised this policy, thus ending it earlier than expected.

NB: this abrogation is probably related to the federal order closing all non-essential public places on 16th March 2020 (following the declaration of "extraordinary situation").
 UPDATE: The original closure of public places providing recreational services was set to last until 30th April 2020, but the Neuchtel state council abrogated the order which comprised this policy on 23rd March 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Public museums/galleries
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government

description: On March 25, Ticino recommends collecting certain waste, such as masks, tissues, hygiene items, etc. in a separate well-closed plastic bag after their use and then in the municipal waste bag. description: On 25th March 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel suspended all statutory time limits for submitting requests for referenda and popular initiatives on cantonal and communal matters. Moreover, the canton suspended the issuance of certificates of eligibility to vote ("attestation de la qualit d'lecteur") for each request (i.e. the validation of signatures: the administration double-checks that each person who signed the request is eligible to vote and issues a document certifying the number of eligible people who have signed the request). During this suspension, signatures cannot be collected for a prospective petition (referenda or initiatives). The statutory time limits for processing requests is also suspended. All these measures are set to last until 31st May 2020.

description:
In Switzerland, the canton from the 2nd of April on the hospitals are exempted from certain regulations within the scope of fulfilling the special regulation (SonderV 20-1).
From the 2nd of April on there will be public social assistance prevention measures. Accordingly, the regulations for responsibilities for case management and assistance changed.
If a municipal or regional social service is unable to perform its duties the municipality has to provide a temporary solution. 
If they cant, the cantonal social service can temporarily transfer responsibility for case management and assistance to another local/ regional social service or another suitable agency.
It would take over the case management and assistance in accordance with the legal requirements applicable in its municipality, if this one is not able to fulfill its duties another appropriate body takes over.
The original municipality must bear the expenses incurred by the newly responsible institution.
The cantonal social service can take appropriate coordination measures and regulate uniform criteria for assuming responsibility in an instruction.

Requests for the granting of cost credits for medical purposes that do not tolerate a delay are to be treated as appropriate and the associated payments as quickly as possible to do.

The cantonal social service can oblige the municipal and regional social services to take over the management of the case for the duration of the ongoing jurisdictional procedure.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On April 3, 2020 in Switzerland the State Chancellery of Canton of Basel-Landschaft announced the standstill of deadlines until May 31:
- For current referendum deadlines, if it is notified of an ongoing collection of signatures within five days of publication of the government resolution
 -  For future State Council resolutions, the State Chancellery shall suspend the deadlines if it is notified of a planned collection of signatures within five days of the publication of a State Council resolution which is subject to an optional popular vote. 
This applies to cantonal and municipal referenda. 
No special regulation is necessary for cantonal and communal initiatives, as the cantonal constitution does not stipulate any collection periods for these.

description: On 16th March 2020, the crisis management task force (ORCCAN) of the Swiss canton of Neuchtel announced the centralization of police services. From 17th March 2020 on, the public can access police counters in only 3 police stations: Neuchtel - BAP, La Chaux-de-Fonds - SISPOL and Fleurier. The other police stations will be closed to the public (although some will remain available by phone). On 7th May 2020, the Neuchtel police added the Htel-de-Ville police station to the list of open police counters. This police station will formally reopen to the public on 11th May 2020. Note that the La-Chaux-de-Fonds-SISPOL station won't be used by the police anymore from 11th May 2020 on, i.e. it will remain closed permanently (not for Covid-related reasons). UPDATE: The original policy closed all police counters except Neuchtel - BAP, La Chaux-de-Fonds - SISPOL and Fleurier, but on 7th May 2020, the Neuchtel police added the Htel-de-Ville police station to the list of open police counters (from 11th May 2020 on).
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 17, 2020 in Switzerland the Government Council of Canton Basel City restricted the use of  public parks, green spaces, squares and the banks of the Rhine. The control of the coronavirus requires everyone to keep their distance from each other, even outdoors. Everyone is urged not to stay for a long time in the recreational areas with large public traffic. Conducting picnics and barbecues is prohibited. Walking or jogging is allowed in the recreation areas. Children with their caregivers may stay in playgrounds. If everyone is considerate of these rules, the parks and public green spaces can remain open. UPDATE: Starting May 30, 20202 the ban on picnics and barbecues in public spaces was lifted when the the federal limit of gathering in public spaces was eased from 5 to 30 persons.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Beaches
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions atttached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: Switzerland, Geneva--The canton supports the general opening of beaches for the summer beginning May 30. This access is for all of the cantons freshwater sites to allow the population a wide choice as to not overwhelm any particular site. "This opening is done under conditions and is accompanied by a strict respect of the behavior instructions, implying in particular the distance of 2 meters between the people, the respect of the barrier gestures and a limitation of the number of people within the same group. . On all the sites, it is also advisable to adopt the usual rules of good behavior and to take the precautions related to swimming in white water."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On 16th March 2020, the crisis management task force (ORCCAN) of the Swiss canton of Neuchtel announced the centralization of police services. From 17th March 2020 on, the public can access police counters in only 3 police stations: Neuchtel - BAP, La Chaux-de-Fonds - SISPOL and Fleurier. The other police stations will be closed to the public (although some will remain available by phone). On 7th May 2020, the Neuchtel police added the Htel-de-Ville police station to the list of open police counters. This police station will formally reopen to the public on 11th May 2020. Note that the La-Chaux-de-Fonds-SISPOL station won't be used by the police anymore from 11th May 2020 on, i.e. it will remain closed permanently (not for Covid-related reasons). On 8th June 2020, the Neuchtel police announced that all police station counters would reopen in the canton, thus ending the original policy. UPDATE: The original policy closed all police counters in Neuchtel (except 3), but on 8th June 2020, the Neuchtel police announced that all policy station counters  would reopen in the canton, thus ending this policy.

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On June 26, the Swiss Canton Ticino implements new health and safety provisions for accessing bathing facilities, precisely public toilets and beaches on the cantonal territory. Every visitor must have at least 7 square meters of space available. At the request of the Cantonal Doctor's Office, the managers must also, if available, immediately provide the contact details of the individual visitors. Those provisions will be valid from 26 June to 31 August.

description:
On March 19, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel Landschaft announced the cancellation of municpal elections and votes scheduled for May 17 and all municipal elections/votes scheduled for June.
The by-elections scheduled for next Sunday ( March 22) can take place.
The term of office for office - holders not already elected on February 9 or March 22, 2020 will be extended until proper renewal elections are held, but not to exceed December 31, 2020. UPDATE: On April 7, 2020 the State Chancellery recommends that the municipalities set aside Sunday, June 28, 2020 as the election date for making up for the cancelled elections which take place by majority voting, in particular the elections of the new mayors and community presidens. For the remaining elections (social welfare authorities, school boards, independent commissions of the municipalities of residents and citizens/burgers, electoral offices), the State Chancellery recommends scheduling them on September 27, 2020, and scheduling the by-elections for November 29, 2020

description: The Swiss Canton Grisons holds the June session of the Grand Council as announced on March 23. The session takes place in the Chur town hall and not as usual in the Grand Council building. The town hall is the only space where social distancing can be guaranteed. No audience is admitted to the session, but a live stream will enable all Council negotiations to be followed directly. UPDATE: On August 11, the Swiss Canton Grisons announces that the August session (25.-28. August) of the Grand Council will also be held in the Chur town hall, as the previous one in June. The same measures regarding the exclusion of the audience, but the provision of live stream apply.

description:
On February 28, 2020 the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that according to the federal ban on public or private events that are attended by more than 1,000 people that in Solothurn a restrictive risk assessment is carried out for events with 100 to 999 participants.
Criteria such as:
    Provide clear information to participants and employees about measures to reduce the risk of transmission (general hygiene measures, coronavirus information for travelers returning, etc.)
    Avoid participation of sick people
    Avoid participation by anyone who has been in an affected area in the past 14 days
    Ensure traceability of participants
    Composition of the audience with regard to risk groups
As a matter of principle, the special staff recommends avoiding events of this size. In any case, the organizer is obliged to consult with the canton for an implementation. A risk assessment is carried out via the hotline (0800 112 117).
 In the case of events with up to 100 people taking part, the organizers are responsible for deciding on the implementation.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On February 28, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel - Landschaft informed  that all events with less than 200 participants can take place. Starting Feb. 28 till March 15 for larger events with 200 to 999 participants, a decision is made in consultation between the organizer and the cantonal authorities ( the Cantonal Crisis Staff KKS ) on the basis of a risk assessment. The following criteria are decisive: 
1. proximity of contact (distance), 2. hygiene measures on site, 3. limitation of the number of participants, 4. traceability of participants and 5. composition of the audience with regard to risk groups.
A new hotline for event organizers is set up.
Event organizing without permittance can be fined.
Events with more than 1000 persons are banned by federal ordinance.

description:
on February 28, 2020 in Switzerland the Departement of Health of Canton Grisons issues an order prohibiting all public or private events of supraregional character or with international participation within the whole cantonal territory. Other ( regional without international participation) events have to undergo a risk assessment by the cantonal authorities.
Non-compliance is to be fined. UPDATE: Origanally only public supraregional events were banned in some regions of Canton Grisons, now all private and public events of supraregional character or international participation are banned within the whole Canton Grisons. Other events have to undergo a risk assessment by the cantonal authorities.

The Swiss federal decision from March 13th to ban events with more than 100 people is adopted by Lucerne and overrules previous policies, it was announced.
 UPDATE: The original restriction prohibited events with people from crisis areas, which was overruled by the federal decision from March 13.

description:
On March 4, 2020 in Switzerland Canton of Neuchatel the Council of State required a risk assessment by the organizers of private or public events hosting less than 500 people. 
An evaluation questionnare will be put online.This is designed as a decision aid (cancellation or maintenance) and allows an event to be assessed on the basis of several criteria:
        the importance of the event
        the ability of the organizers to identify the participants 
        the confinement of the premises
        the type of activities planned

description: On March 4, 2020 in Switzerland the Departement of Health of Canton Grisons specified its order concerning mass gathering. Prohibited are outdoor events with more than 500 persons, indoor events with more than 300 seated persons (except there are more than 4 squaremeter per person) or indoor events with more than 150 freely circulating persons. All other events have to undergo a risk assessment by the cantonal administration. Non-compliance is to be fined. UPDATE: Before events without international participation and less then 1000 participants were subject to governmental risk assessment. Now the limit is set to 500 persons for outdoor events or 300 seated persons indoor or 150 persons indoor freely circulating.

On March 6, the Swiss Canton of Freiburg released a protocol on the by the federal government announced restriction of mass gatherings of more than 1000 people. The protocol outlines conditions of necessary hygiene measures, participation of vulnerable persons, and the special investigation of events of more than 150 participants. On March 16, this policy was succeeded by tightened measures. UPDATE: On March 16, the Canton announced a new policy on mass gatherings, which originates from the State Council and hence would be a new policy.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

Following the criteria developed by the Federal Office of Public Health and the Conference of Health Directors from Monday, March 9, 2020. Events with 150 to 1,000 participants can still be held in the canton of Schaffhausen if the risk is weighed up and the framework conditions  by the FOPH are observed: Persons at risk should be advised not to take part, information about protective measures, people who are sick or who feel sick should be asked not to attend or leave the event

It was recommend to authorities, companies and others to refrain from all activities, events and meetings in which fewer than 50 people take part.
The health ministry on Appenzell-Ausserrhoden (Switzerland recommends, not to attend any event on March 13.

description:
At its meeting on March 13, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided on further measures: With immediate effect and until April 30, the council bans all public or private events with more than 100 people. The limit of 100 persons also applies to leisure and entertainment facilities. Cantonal authorities can approve exceptions for reasons of public interest. Events and gatherings with less than 100 participants can take place provided that measures are taken
a. to exclude people who are sick or who feel sick 
b. to protect persons belonging to a risk group
c. measures to inform those present about protective measures such as hand hygiene, keeping their distance or coughing and runny nose hygiene
d. Adaptation of the spatial conditions so that the hygiene rules can be adhered to."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

UPDATE: The ban on events with more than 100 participants ends March 13,2020 as the federal Government decrees a stricter ban on mass gatherings.

description:
On February 28th, 2020 the Federal Council of Switzerland bans public and private events in Switzerland at which more than 1000 people would gather. This ban on events comes into effect immediately and will last until at least March 15.The cantons are responsible for enforcing the ban.
In the case of public or private events at which fewer than 1000 people would gather, event organisers must carry out a risk assessment in conjunction with the competent cantonal authorities to decide whether or not the event can be held.
This policy was abrogated already on March 13. UPDATE: The ban on large scale events was scheduled to last till March 15 but was abrogated on March 13, when a new ordinance was issued banning gatherings with more than 100 participants.

description:
On March 5th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced a set of conditions for mass gatherings of 150 to 999 people:
   
   The gathering must be registered at least 48 hours in advance to the Service of Public Health ("Service de la sant publique") via the email address manifestations@jura.ch by using a form available on www.jura.ch/coronavirus;
   
  The "self-declaration" form available on www.jura.ch/coronavirus needs to be adequately filled in by the organizers. By filling it, the organizers pledge to: display, in a very clear manner, the sanitary, collective and individual measures recommended by the Federal Office of Public Health ("Office fdral de la sant publique"); to warn vulnerable populations against attending the event (people aged over 65 and in particular, people with the chronic illnesses stated in the circular); to refuse access to the event to anyone who is ill or feels ill and to order these individuals to leave the gathering.

 UPDATE: On March 13th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced that all gatherings above 100 people were forbidden until April 4th. For restaurants, bars and clubs, the limit was set to 50.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The Swiss federal government announced that events with more then 1000 persons are prohibited. The authorities of the canton Schaffhausen said as a reaction to this federal policy that events with less then 1000 persons are still allowed on February 28th 2020. UPDATE: On March 13, 2020 this policy ended when it was overruled by the federal ban on all events with more than 100 persons.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On February 28, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel - Landschaft informed  that all events with less than 200 participants can take place. Starting Feb. 28 till March 15 for larger events with 200 to 999 participants, a decision is made in consultation between the organizer and the cantonal authorities ( the Cantonal Crisis Staff KKS ) on the basis of a risk assessment. The following criteria are decisive: 
1. proximity of contact (distance), 2. hygiene measures on site, 3. limitation of the number of participants, 4. traceability of participants and 5. composition of the audience with regard to risk groups.
A new hotline for event organizers is set up.
Event organizing without permittance can be fined.
Events with more than 1000 persons are banned by federal ordinance. UPDATE: This policy ended when it got overruled by a federal ordinance banning all gathering with more than 100 persons starting March 13, 2020, 3.30 pm.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On March 4, 2020 in Switzerland Canton of Neuchatel the Council of State required a risk assessment by the organizers of private or public events hosting less than 500 people. 
An evaluation questionnare will be put online.This is designed as a decision aid (cancellation or maintenance) and allows an event to be assessed on the basis of several criteria:
        the importance of the event
        the ability of the organizers to identify the participants 
        the confinement of the premises
        the type of activities planned
This policy was ended on March 15 by another cantonal policy banning all mass gatherings (in a confined or outdoor space), except necessary meetings of maximum 20 people. UPDATE: The original policy restricted mass gatherings by requiring a risk assessment for events bringing together less than 500 people in a confined space. On March 15, the Canton banned all mass gatherings (in a confined or outdoor space), except necessary meetings of less than 20 people, which ended the original policy.

On 15th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel prohibited all public or private mass gatherings (in a confined or outdoor space), except for necessary meetings bringing together less than 20 people, until 30th April 2020. On 23rd March 2020, the Canton abrogated the order which comprised this policy, thus ending it earlier than expected.

NB: this abrogation is probably related to federal prohibition of all mass gatherings on 20th March 2020
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On March 15, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel Landschaft announced that starting March 16 until April 30 all public, private and religious events as well as events or gatherings with more than 50 persons are prohibited.                                                                                 
The cantonal government may exceptionally permit events with more than 50 persons if overriding public interests so require( for the exercise of political rights). Such applications must be submitted to the cantonal crisis staff (KKS) with a protection concept concerning compliance with the rules of the FOPH.
All activities of clubs and similar organizations such as sports events, training sessions, rehearsals, etc. are prohibited.
Non- compliance can be fined.

description:
At its meeting on March 13, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided on further measures: With immediate effect and until April 30, the council bans all public or private events with more than 100 people. The limit of 100 persons also applies to leisure and entertainment facilities. Cantonal authorities can approve exceptions for reasons of public interest. Events and gatherings with less than 100 participants can take place provided that measures are taken
a. to exclude people who are sick or who feel sick 
b. to protect persons belonging to a risk group
c. measures to inform those present about protective measures such as hand hygiene, keeping their distance or coughing and runny nose hygiene
d. Adaptation of the spatial conditions so that the hygiene rules can be adhered to.
This policy ended prematurely on March 16. UPDATE: The ban on gatherings of over 100 people was set to last till April 30. This policy ended prematurely as of March 16, when all events were prohibited.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
On March 13, 2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Valais prohibited all public or private events involving more than 50 people starting March 13.
Sporting and cultural activities and group events, both professional and amateur athletes, of every type and category, regardless of the number of people present were prohibited.
It was recommend to authorities, companies and others to refrain from all activities, events and meetings in which fewer than 50 people take part.
 UPDATE: On March 16, 2020 this policy ended prematurely when the State Council of Canton Valais prohibited all events and gatherings starting March 16, 6.30 pm.

On March 15, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel Landschaft announced that starting March 16 until April 30 all public, private and religious events as well as events or gatherings with more than 50 persons are prohibited.                                                                                 
The cantonal government may exceptionally permit events with more than 50 persons if overriding public interests so require( for the exercise of political rights). Such applications must be submitted to the cantonal crisis staff (KKS) with a protection concept concerning compliance with the rules of the FOPH.
All activities of clubs and similar organizations such as sports events, training sessions, rehearsals, etc. are prohibited.
Non- compliance can be fined. UPDATE: On March 16, 2020 this policy ended when it got overruled by the federal policy banning all events starting March 16 midnight.

description: The Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of private and public gatherings of 50 or more people from March 16 to April 30, 2020, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of less than 50 people are obliged to follow the hygiene recommendations of the Federal Health Agency. Public transport is exempt from this regulation. On March 20, the policy was strengthened to gatherings of more than 5 people, while no end date was included in the policy protocol anymore. Penalties of 100-150 Swiss Francs for individuals, and 2000-5000 Francs for businesses, and legal prosecution were also announced for a breach of the measures. UPDATE: On March 20, the restriction of mass gatherings was strengthened to a limit of more than 5 people while an end date of the policy was not implied anymore.

description: On March 21, Switzerland,  Ticino prohibits all organized or spontaneous gatherings with more than five people. Violations of the prohibitions can be punished with a disciplinary fine of CHF 100.-

On March 20, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council banned gathering of more than five people in public as of March 21st. Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined.
As before (start March 17, 2020) all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, markets, religious services, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home ( but not recommended), funerals in close family circle, playing children (in  groups of five) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4 qm in closed rooms.
 UPDATE: The ban on all public and private events ( March 16) still allowed private gathering in small groups. The Swiss federal council will now ban any gathering of more than five people in public spaces as of March 21st (announced March 20th), every persons has to socially distance ( 2m), non-compliance can be fined.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In the Canton of Zurich, Switzerland gatherings of groups with 15 or more persons in attendance are getting disbanded by police and reminded that they should "socially distance themselves" effective March 18th. UPDATE: With the national implementation of a limit of 5 persons gathering in public spaces this policy ends on March 20.

On March 20,2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Jura decided that all cantonal and communal elections are postponed until further decision. 
This also applies when the voting materials have already been distributed to voters (e.g. election in Genevez scheduled March 22).
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
Switzerland, Geneva--"The cantonal police, with the support of the Civil Protection (PCi), proceeded this morning, Saturday March 28, to a cordon of the lakeside surroundings in order to prohibit the parking of private vehicles. The objective of this measure is to severely restrict the gatherings of people in the same place as part of the fight against the spread of the COVID-19 virus."

Original: La police cantonale, avec l'appui de la Protection civile (PCi), a procd ce matin, samedi 28 mars,  un bouclage des abords lacustres afin d'interdire le stationnement des vhicules privs. L'objectif de cette mesure est de restreindre fortement les rassemblements de personnes sur un mme lieu dans le cadre de la lutte contre la propagation du virus COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On March 16, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council banned all public or private events, including parties, sports events, political demonstrations and General assemblies as of March 17.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups ( in public spaces and at home), playing children (recommended group size 5) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4qm in closed rooms. This was scheduled to end April 19th.
On April 8th the Federal Council decided to extend the ban on events and gatherings by one week till April 26th. UPDATE: The ban on events and gathering in groups of more than five persons was set to last till April 19, it has been extended till April 26.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 22nd April 2020, the state council of the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel decided to ban all mass gatherings bringing together several hundreds of people up until 21st June 2020 at the earliest. 

NB: this policy echoes the "deconfinement plan" released by the Swiss Federal Council on 16th April 2020, which reaffirms the ban on mass gatherings but doesn't give any end date to this ban. The Neuchtel state council specified in their news release that they were giving the date of 21st June 2020 to clarify the situation and give more visibility to event organizers.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On 24th April 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel decided to postpone to 2021 the cross-cultural festival NeuchToi, which was supposed to occur from 30th August to 30th October 2020. A new date hasn't been set yet for this annually recurring event which should have celebrated its 5th year in 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On April 24, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Jura announced that the holding of municipal assemblies, meetings of general councils or city councils remain suspended. These meetings and sessions may resume from May 25, 2020. UPDATE: Parliamentary sessions and municipal assemblies were canceled till further notice, now they can resume starting May 25.

Churches are allowed to open, but no services or events are allowed. Everything else stays closed (e.g. cinemas) or forbidden. (e.g. partys) UPDATE: Some are allowed to open again, but most of the restricted areas are prolonged until May 10th

description:
On April 16, 2020 at its meeting the Swiss Federal Council decided the next steps for gradually easing measures against coronavirus after April 27. The restriction whereby funerals may only be attended by close family will also be lifted as of April 27th, provided a protection concept complying to the guidelines of the Federal Office of Health.
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till May 10th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, markets, religious services, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished. Gathering of more than five people in public is still banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home ( but not recommended), playing children (in groups of five) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4 qm in closed rooms, funerals. UPDATE: The ban on gathering over five persons and all public and private events was set to last till April 26th, it has been extended till May 10th. But the restrictions on funerals have been relaxed, from funerals in close family circle to funerals in larger family circle.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 29 April, the Federal Council decided that measures to combat coronavirus in the area of sport would also be relaxed as of 11 May. From 11 May, sports training will be possible again under certain conditions, both in popular and competitive sport. The federal government's hygiene regulations must be strictly adhered to and appropriate protection concepts are necessary. The umbrella associations of the individual sports provide sample concepts for this purpose. The Canton of Zug will carry out spot checks on clubs and sports facility operators and support them in implementing the requirements.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On April 29, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided at its meeting on the next steps to relax the measures against the coronavirus. From May 11th, sports clubs can resume training for amateur athletes in groups of five and without physical contact and with more exceptions for competitive athletes (permanent teams). Markets can take place.
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till presumably June 7 th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, other club activities, religious services, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished. Gathering of more than five people in public is still banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined. 
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home, playing children at school play-grounds and business meetings (limited to 1 person per 4 qm), funerals (in a family-closed friends-circle), training of competitive athletes in permanent teams, markets. UPDATE: The ban on gathering over five persons and on all public and private events was set to last till May 10th, it has been extended till June 7th. But more exemptions are allowed.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of private and public gatherings of 50 or more people from March 16 to April 30, 2020, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of less than 50 people are obliged to follow the hygiene recommendations of the Federal Health Agency. Public transport is exempt from this regulation. From May 19, the cantonal leadership body (KFO) decided to exempt meetings of club directorates from the restriction of mass gatherings of no more than 5 people. UPDATE: From May 19, the cantonal leadership body (KFO) decided to exempt meetings of club directorates from the restriction of mass gatherings of no more than 5 people.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is requiring a notification for events with less than 1000 participants and international participation
( in addition to the federal ban on events with more than 1000 participants). All carnival activities are forbidden. UPDATE: The original measure for the restriction on mass gathering was introduced on February 28 with the obligation of permission for more than 1.000 people. As of March 7 gatherings of more than 150 people were forbidden and as of March 12 gatherings of more than 50 people. On March 21 further restrict gathering to a maximum of 5 people. As of May 30 gatherings of up to 30 people are allowed and on June 6 manifestations with up to 300 participants.

On May 20, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced  that faith communities should be able to resume their common religious life. From the 28th of May 2020, all services and celebrations of all faiths will once again be permitted. The religious communities have one week to work out protection concepts and to ensure the tracing of possible chains of infection. A framework protection concept has been drawn up by the Federal Office of Public Health (FOPH). UPDATE: The ban on gathering over five persons and on all public and private events was set to last till June 7th. But religious services were allowed to resume prematurely as of May 28th ( announced May 20) without limit in number of participants.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On May 27, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided at its meeting on further easing the measures put in place to fight the new coronavirus starting May 30. 
Till and including May 29 gathering of more than five people in public is  banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined. 
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till presumably June 7 th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished. 
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home, playing children at school play-grounds and business meetings, training of competitive athletes in permanent teams, amateur sports in groups of five, markets, religious services and celebrations including funerals (protection concept).
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description:
On May 27th, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council decided: The ban on gatherings in public, in particular in public spaces, promenades and parks is to be eased. As of 30 May, the upper limit will be increased from 5 to 30 people.
Gathering in groups over 30 persons can be fined, not adhering to social distancing rules is no longer to be fined. Nevertheless social distancing remains highly recommended. Exempted are school children at school playgrounds.

description: The Swiss Canton Ticino announces that 30 people are allowed to gather as of May 30, instead of only 5. UPDATE: The limit of people gathering of max 5 people from March 2, is eased to max 30 as of May 30.

On April 24,2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Jura announced that the suspension in effect of known time limits on political rights will end on May 31, 2020, as at the federal level. Voting and elections may in particular resume from June 1 st .

 UPDATE: The original annulation of cantonal and municipal elections was set to last till further notice, now elections resume after May 31.

description: On June 3, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden announced that contrary to its prior announcement, it would hold a high school graduation ceremony, albeit in a reduced form following strict hygiene measures.

description:
On May 27, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided that 
from June 6th, private and public events with up to 300 people are to be allowed.This includes family events, fairs, concerts, club activities, sports events/competitions, theatre performances and film screenings, general assemblies,as well as political and civil society demonstrations.
On condition that all events have appropriate sets of precautionary measures in place. Hygiene and social distancing rules must still be observed. If it is not possible to respect social distancing rules, contact tracing must be assured, by means of attendance lists, for example. 
Summer holiday camps for children and young people will be allowed to go ahead from 6 June as long as appropriate sets of precautionary measures are in place. Children and young people should remain in the same groups wherever possible. The upper limit for camps is 300 people and organisers must keep an attendance list.
Cantons can allow exemptions for important reasons. Non-public events ( family events, club activities where people know each other) with less than 30 persons only have to ensure contact tracing.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 11th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel specified the details of the mandatory protection plan for all public mass gatherings between 30 and 300 people. The organizer of the event will have to submit an application to the Department of Consumption and Veterinary Affairs specifying the name of the person in charge of the Covid safety measures. If the 2 meters social distancing cannot be respected, contact tracing has to be implemented by listing the names and phone numbers of participants; this data shall be stored for 14 days and made available to the government if need be.

NB: this policy follows on from the federal government's announcement on 6th June 2020 that mass gatherings up to 300 people could be organized in Switzerland, as long as they have a protection plan.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 11th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel announced that private mass gatherings of up to 300 people (in compliance with the 6th June 2020 federal policy allowing mass gatherings up to 300 people) can be organized without a protection plan (i.e. a document to be submitted to the canton), but hygiene and social distancing measures have to be respected. If they can't be respected, contact tracing has to be implemented by collecting the personal data (names, phone numbers) of participants.

description: On July 3, the Swiss Canton Ticino limits the maximal number of people gathering back to 30 and the number of people in bars, night clubs, discotheques to 100 people maximum. This policy is implemented immediately until July 19. UPDATE: As of June 22 the decision from the Federal Government allowed gatherings of more than 30 people and manifestations with max 1.000 participants if distances could be guaranteed. With raising cases, the Swiss Canton Ticino announced on July 3, that the number of people gathering will be again limited to 30 persons and max 100 in night bars and clubs, to be implemented immediately until July 19.

description: On July 8th, the government of the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that public and private events for 101 to 1000 people would have to be conducted in seperate rooms for a maximum of 100 people each. This number excludes active participants (e.g. actors, artists). Furthermore, event organizers would have to identify, record and verify contact data of all visitors. This policy was scheduled to take into effect on July 9th and expire on August 31st.

description:
On July 8, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Basel-Landschaft starting July 9 till August 31 requires a subdivision of public and private events with more than 100 persons at which neither the required distance can be maintained nor protective measures are taken, and therefore contact data must be collected (according to the federal  Covid-19 Ordinance special situation). A subdivision into standing or seated sectors with a maximum of 100 people must be made. In addition, outside these sectors, if there is a possibility of mixing, either the minimum distance must be maintained or a protective mask must be worn.
Events with more than 1000 persons are banned by the federal government.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: In Switzerland, Aargau the cantonal medical service strengthens the national guidelines regarding events from July 9, 2020 until August 16. If over 100 persons and a maximum of 1000 persons are present, they must be split into groups of 100 persons per sector.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On 28. February, the Canton Zug, Switzerland releases restrictions of mass gathering. Public and private events which host 200 people or where persons from risk areas take place need to be registered. From 3. March until 15. March this in force. UPDATE: On 10 Juli the Regierungsrat Kanton Zug decided to add the following restrictions to the national measures. Events with more than 300 people present may only be held if the required distance is maintained or if protective measures such as wearing a face mask are taken.
For events with more than 30 and not more than 300 participants
if the required distance is not maintained or protective measures are not taken, contact details must be collected and a division into sectors or groups of no more than 30 persons indoors or no more than 100 persons outdoors. For events for family or friends with a maximum of 100 people present, which do not take place in establishments or companies open to the public, only the federal regulations apply. For events with up to 30 persons as well as for political and civil society rallies, only the federal legal requirements apply.
This decision takes force on 13 July and until 31 August.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On 28. February, the Canton Zug, Switzerland releases restrictions of mass gathering. Public and private events which host 200 people or where persons from risk areas take place need to be registered. From 3. March until 15. March this in force. UPDATE: From Monday, 13 July, the following rules will take effect in the Canton of Zug:

    over 300 people:

Events with more than 300 people present may only be held if the minimum distance of 1.5 metres between those present can be maintained or protective measures such as wearing a protective mask are taken.

    31-300 persons:
        If the minimum distance can be maintained or protective measures (e.g. wearing a mask) can be taken at events with between 31 and 300 people present, these events may be held without additional restrictions.
        If this is not possible, the participants must be divided into sectors of maximum 30 persons indoors and maximum 100 persons outdoors. In this case, contact details must also be collected.
        No sectors need to be formed for events with family or friends of up to 100 people present.

    Up to 30 persons:

Smaller events with less than 30 people present can still take place without any conditions
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On 10 Juli the Regierungsrat Kanton Zug decided to add the following restrictions to the national measures: In the interiors of restaurants, including bars and clubs as well as discotheques and dance halls, a maximum of 30 guests may be present at any one time. In the entire guest area of these establishments, including any outdoor areas, a maximum of 100 guests may be present at any one time. The outdoor areas must be clearly recognisable or marked. The contact data must be recorded, regardless of whether the guests enter the interior of the holding or stay only in outside areas ten. 
The decision shall enter into force on 13 July and is in force until 31 August. 
 UPDATE: On 11 May 2020, shops, restaurants, travel agencies, fitness studios, markets, museums, libraries, etc. may reopen, provided they have a protection concept and apply the known hygiene measures. Distance and hygiene rules remain valid
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On July 15, 2020, the Swiss canton of Lucerne announced that despite the federal limit of 300 people for public and private events, it would lower the limit to a maximum of 100 if social distancing, mask wearing, or other protective measures cannot be guaranteed. In this case, closed sectors with a maximum of 100 people need to be established.

description: On July 16, the Swiss Canton Ticino extends the measures implemented on July 3, i.e. the restrictions of mass gatherings up to 30 persons and the limitation of 100 customers in bars and restaurants, until August 9. UPDATE: The original end of date of the new measures was July 19, however they were extended until August 9.

On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is requiring a notification for events with less than 1000 participants and international participation
( in addition to the federal ban on events with more than 1000 participants). All carnival activities are forbidden. UPDATE: On August 6, the Swiss Canton Ticino extends the current measures in place regarding the restrictions of mass gatherings up to 30 persons in public spaces (including parks and sidewalks). The policy is extended until August 24.

On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is requiring a notification for events with less than 1000 participants and international participation
( in addition to the federal ban on events with more than 1000 participants). All carnival activities are forbidden. UPDATE: On August 19, the Swiss Canton Ticino extends the current measures in place regarding the restrictions of mass gatherings up to 30 persons in public spaces (including parks and sidewalks). The policy is extended until September 7.

From Saturday, August 22nd onwards, events for 100 people or more may only be held if the minimum distance can be maintained or masks are worn. In return, up to 100 people are again allowed in the indoor areas of clubs and bars at the same time, so that the same rules apply to all establishments and events.

description:
On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is requiring a notification for events with less than 1000 participants and international participation
( in addition to the federal ban on events with more than 1000 participants). All carnival activities are forbidden. UPDATE: On September 2, the Swiss Canton Ticino extends the current measures in place regarding the restrictions of mass gatherings up to 30 persons in public spaces (including parks and sidewalks). The policy is extended until September 21.
Appenzell-Ausserrhoden (Switzerland) cancells the annual animal schows ("Viehschauen") from mid-september to mid-october 2020 on July 7.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On September 15th 2020, the Canton of Vaud announced a ban on private events of 100 people or more.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On September 15th 2020, the Canton of Vaud announced a ban on private events of 100 people or more.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: In Zurich (Switzerland) events with over 100 participants must provide a safety concept from August 24. UPDATE: The original policy was also set to last until September 30, it has been extended to October 31.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
link: NA ; Regierungsrat Zrich ; Verordnung ber Massnahmen zur Bekmpfung der Covid-19-Epidemie

description: In accordance with federal regulations decided upon on August 12, the Swiss canton of Obwalden begins to allow events with over 1000 attendees under certain conditions, if the number of infections remains low: All such events must be approved by the cantonal administration. The application for the event must be submitted at least one month in advance except for events in October, where the deadline is 10 days before the scheduled date. Organizers must outline a hygiene concept to ensure hygiene and social distancing, visitors must remain seated during the event, and the flow of people must be regulated. Furthermore, there must be a plan for the handling of suspected cases.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: In accordance with federal regulations decided upon on August 12, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden begins to allow events with over 1000 attendees under certain conditions, if the number of infections remains low and the canton has sufficient capacities for contact tracing: All such events must be approved by the cantonal administration. The application for the event must be submitted at least six weeks in advance except for events before November 8, which can be approved at shorter notice. Organizers must outline a hygiene concept to ensure hygiene and social distancing, visitors must remain seated during the event, seats must be assigned to specific individuals, and the flow of people must be regulated. Furthermore, there must be a plan for the handling of suspected cases.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On September 24, 2020, the Swiss canton of Uri issued its guidelines for the approval of mass events (over 1000 participants) based on federal guidelines, effective from October 1. Organizers must submit an application in advance and outline a hygiene concept. Visitors of an event must be seated on personalised spots, social distancing and hygiene must be ensured at all times, and there must be a procedure to handle suspected cases. Events can only be approved if the number of infections s low enough and the capacities for contact tracing at the local authorities are ensured. Permits can be revoked if any of the aforementioned conditions is no longer met.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: Following federal guidelines on the approval for the permission with over 1000 participants after October 1, the Swiss canton of Schwyz announced its guidelines for the permission of such events on September 10: Organizers must apply for permission in advance and outline a hygiene concept. Visitors must be seated during the event, and seats must be assigned to a specific individual. Furthermore, infection rates in the canton must be low enough and authorities must be able to ensure contact tracing for events to be approved.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On September 25, 2020 the Swiss Canton Grisons announces that mass gatherings (like concerts, sport events etc.) with over 1000 participants will be allowed again starting October 1, 2020. This measure was initiated after the "Bundesrat", the national parliament of Switzerland, decided on August 12, 2020, that mass gatherings with over 1000 participants should be allowed again starting October 1. The organizer of the mass gathering has to submit an application to the Cantonal health department at least 20days before the event. Also an protection concept must be submitted. At the end the the Canton has to approve or withdraw each event individually depending on the epidemiological situation.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
link: NA ; https://www.gr.ch/DE/Medien/Mitteilungen/MMStaka/2020/Seiten/2020081205.aspx ; Grisons Official Website ; Coronavirus: Kanton prft Vorgaben fr Grossanlsse

description: The goverment of the Swiss Canton Saint Gallen announced on September 18, 2020, that mass gatherings with over 1000 participants will be allowed again starting October 1, 2020.This measure was initiated after the "Bundesrat", the Swiss national parliament decided on August 20, 2020 that mass gatherings with over 1000 participants should be allowed again. This measure must be implemented by the Cantons.  The event organizer first has to submit a application with a safety concept to the state health department and the county, where the mass gathering should take place. If the epidemiological situation should get worse a permission also can be withdrawn
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: From August 27 until September 30 in Zurich (Switzerland) indoor events with more than 100 people are prohibited unless participants are wearing face masks or maintain the required distance. If a precautionary measures plan is implemented events with more than 100 people are still permitted within the framework of national guidelines. If the event takes place both indoors and outdoors, these protective measures must be taken if more than 300 people attend. UPDATE: From October 15th 2020 participants of events inside with more than 30 people have to wear masks if the required distance cannot be kept.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The Swiss Canton Saint Gallen announced on October 16, 2020, that masks will be mandatory for groups with 30 or more persons for private and public envents when social distancing measures aren't applicable. Schools are not affected by this measure. This measure starts on October 17, 2020 and is applicalbe until December 31, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On July 8, 2020, the Swiss canton of Basel City announced that despite a federal limit of 300 people per sector on public and private events, it would lower this limit to 100 if social distancing and other protective measures cannot be guaranteed. UPDATE: On October 18, 2020 the Federal Council announced more restrictions for private events starting October 19. The cantonal ordinance was changed accordingly.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On July 8, 2020, the Swiss canton of Basel City announced that despite a federal limit of 300 people per sector on public and private events, it would lower this limit to 100 if social distancing and other protective measures cannot be guaranteed. UPDATE: On October 16, the limit for public and private events was set to 50 persons if social distancing or other protective measures ( e.g. masks, plexiglass panes) cannot be guaranteed starting  Oct.19. till December 31. Subdivision into sectors is no longer possible, as before contact data have to be collected.

description: On October 15, 2020, the cantonal government of Thurgau announces that for public and private events of 30 to 1,000 persons or more that take place on or after October 23, 2020, it is obligatory for the organizer of the event to register the event 14 days prior at www.tg.ch/coronavirus. In addition, events of 30+ persons require a hygiene concept and contact details records of all attandences.

description: On 18th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel decided to postpone the municipal election ("lections communales") that was supposed to take place on 14th June 2020. A new date for the election is still to be chosen and discussed with the municipalities in the canton. On 4th May 2020, the state council of the Canton of Neuchtel chose 25th October 2020 as the new date for the election, thus ending the original policy. UPDATE: The original postponement of the municipal election had no end date because the canton of Neuchtel had not chosen a new date for the election. On 4th May 2020, the canton decided that the election would occur on 25th October 2020, thus ending the policy.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Switzerland, Ticino announces that from November 9, 2020 gatherings in public spaces with more than five people as well as public and private events with more than five participants are prohibited.
With a few exceptions (U16, professional teams, national teams), all group sports activities are prohibited.

description: Due to the high new infections rate, the goverment of the Swiss Canton Grisons announced on December 4, 2020, that gatherings, events and sport acitivities with over 10 persons are prohibited. Exceptions are possible for sport activities for person under the age of 16 and religious occasions for up to 50 persons are possible, when other measures like social distancing can be complied. This measure starts on December 4, 2020 and will end on December 17, 2020.

description:
On March 6th, 2020 at its press conference the Swiss Federal council and the Federal Office of Health released recommendations (factsheet)  for the population including the advice to keep distance .

chirurgical/ hygiene masks are recommended for

description: On March 17th the Canton Uri released an instruction to clarify how the measures by the federal government are being implemented in the Canton. The implemention includs a social-distancing protocol, which states that people should keep a distance of 2 meters. Groups shouldn't be bigger than 5 people and people are asked to pay by card and not cash.

description: The Canton Government of St Gallen extends the deadline for handing in tax returns to May 31st due to social distancing regulations on March 19th 2020.
In order to avoid crowding during the surrounding days, the Swiss canton of Schwyz will allow essential shops to open on the public holiday 'Josefstag' on March 19. The opening will be voluntary.

description: The City of Bern, Switzerland closes the Bundesterrasse and other parks effective March 20th

On March 20, 2020, it was announced that the police in the canton of Lucerne, Switzerland, is using speakers to inform the population to keep distance and to avoid large group gatherings. Patrols in shops and restaurants are intensified.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The Swiss Federal Council asks that all residents comply with social distancing regulations, including no meetings of more than five people and a complete vacation of public spaces e.g. parks from March 20th onwards. UPDATE: Social distancing recommendations enlarged from at-risk groups to general population, with fines introuduced

On March 20, 2020:
Because people have not being fully complying with the rules on social distancing the Swiss Federal Council has decided that in public places people must keep a distance of at least two metres from each other starting March 21 till April 19. The police may impose a fine for non-compliance.

Valais (Switzerland) recommends all citizens on March 24 to conduct necessary outgoings at locations and times where people are as isolated as possible and distance to others is respected as well as to stay at the balkony in the sun to minimize the risk of infection. If people seem to be infected, they should contact their doctor via phone first to reduce people staying in doctors offices.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The cable railway which connects the valley and the village Braunwald in the canton Glarus is limited to the local village population to decrease the chance of infection with the corona virus. Tourists are prohibited from using the cable railway. This policy followed the decision of the Swiss federal government to shut down every touristic cable railway and skiing lift. Only the local population is allowed to use them. This policy was announced on March 27, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams

description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided to temporarily change the regulation on electronic signatures. The change provides a general way of video identification when issuing certificates, making physical signatures redundant. This way, trips and personal contacts can be avoided UPDATE: The social distancing regulations have been expanded by temporarily allowing electronic signatures and verifications for a maximum period of 6 months to avoid social contact, starting April 1st 2020.

The Swiss Federal Council has made adjustments to the asylum procedure in Switzerland which is to be coordinated across all cantons from April 1st 2020. The changes include greater physical distance in the asylum interview process (fewer individuals in the room etc) and additional accommodation for asylum applicants who are unable to leave due to COVID-19 to be made by converting military accommodation.
On April 2nd the city of Luzern, Switzerland closes a number of public spaces as people do not adhere to Social Distancing

The Canton of Zug urges its population to avoid travel over Easter and avoid popular outdoor areas such as the lake shore and hiking paths in order to comply with federal measures, the police will be deployed to ensure compliance, on April 8th 2020.

Switzerland, Geneva--Traffic restrictions will go into place throughout the canton from Friday April 10, 2020 to Monday April 13, 2020 for the Easter holiday. Access will be limited to residents and certain car parks will be closed in these areas:

All other persons are asked to shop later. description: The Swiss Federal Council releases new guidelines for protecting at-risk employees from returning to work prematurely on April 16th in light of corona restrictions being eased. If an individual considers their health to be at risk by returning to work their employer must facilitate work from home through giving the employee alternative tasks or other means. Wages must continue to be paid to those unable to return to the workplace for health reasons.

The implemention includs a social-distancing protocol, which states that people should keep a distance of 2 meters. Groups shouldn't be bigger than 5 people and people are asked to pay by card and not cash. 

April 23rd: 
Prolonged until May 10th UPDATE: Prolonged until May 10th

description:
On March 6th, 2020 at its press conference the Swiss Federal council and the Federal Office of Health released recommendations (factsheet)  for the population including the advice to keep distance .
On its website ( March 5 ) the FOPH recommends: " Keep your distance e.g. protect the elderly by keeping a save distance. Keep your distance from others in a queue. Keep your distance at meetings." UPDATE: On April 16, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided that from 27 April it will begin to ease the measures put in place.The social distancing rules continue to be important and will remain in place. This applies until May 10, 2020. (Covid 19 ordinance 2 Art.7c).
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description:
On March 6th, 2020 at its press conference the Swiss Federal council and the Federal Office of Health released recommendations (factsheet)  for the population including the advice to keep distance .
On its website ( March 5 ) the FOPH recommends: " Keep your distance e.g. protect the elderly by keeping a save distance. Keep your distance from others in a queue. Keep your distance at meetings." UPDATE: The FOPH  announced on June 5th that the Federal Council has abolished (on May 30) the fine for non-compliance with the distance. (Covid 19 Ordinance 2 change Art. 7c valid from May 30 till July 5). The recommendations on distance are not applicable to people for whom compliance is inappropriate, in particular to schoolchildren, parents with their children or people who can be shown to live in the same household.

On June 19, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced that there is no upper limit for the number of people able to attend a demonstration, but it will be mandatory to wear a face mask. This change concerning political and civil society demonstrations will apply from Saturday, 20 June.
Gathering of less than 30 persons are excepted from mask obligation.

description:
On March 6th, 2020 at its press conference the Swiss Federal council and the Federal Office of Health released recommendations (factsheet)  for the population including the advice to keep distance .
On its website ( March 5 ) the FOPH recommends: " Keep your distance e.g. protect the elderly by keeping a save distance. Keep your distance from others in a queue. Keep your distance at meetings." UPDATE: On June 19, 2020 in view of the low number of cases, the Swiss Federal Council is reducing the minimum distance that should be kept between two people from 2 metres to 1.5 metres starting June 22. If masks are worn or partitions are in place, the distance may be further reduced.

description:
At its meeting on 1 July, the SwissFederal Council has decided to make masks compulsory on public transport throughout the country from Monday, 6 July. Persons over the age of 12 will have to wear a mask in trains, trams and buses, as well as on mountain rail and cableways and on lake and river boats.
An urgent recommendation is already in place to wear a mask when travelling on public transport at peak times.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Federal Council has decided on July 1st that as of July 6th travelers in public transport must wear a face mask in all vehicles. This now also applies to aircraft as of August 12ve.
This does not apply to: a. Children before their 12th birthday; b. People who can prove that they are unable to wear face masks for special reasons, particularly medical ones.
The measure affects all scheduled and charter flights that take off or land in Switzerland, regardless of the airline.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On August 5, 2020 in Switzerland the Departement of Education in Canton Basel-City anounced that after summer break ( August 10th)  the "Mittelschulen" ( upper secondary age above 15) and vocational schools are faced with the challenge of complying with the distance rules by the Federal Office of Health. Where this is not possible, masks and plexiglass solutions can be used.
Schools made extensive changes in the classrooms in order to enable teaching in full classes.This also includes the purchase of additional individual desks. In this way, a general mask requirement can be avoided during lessons. A mask requirement should only exist where the distances cannot be maintained, e.g. practical training, in training workshops, in laboratory lessons.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On August 20, 2020 due to the increasing number of infections, the Government Council of Swiss Canton Basel City decided to make wearing a mask compulsory (effective Monday August 24th) on the school premises of upper secondary schools (age above 15 years) and higher education institutions. Since the safety distance can be maintained in the classrooms of upper secondary schools, lessons continue to take place without masks. First and foremost, certified or compliant masks are recommended. Scarves or other non-specific textiles are not face masks in the present sense.

description: On October 15, 2020, the cantonal government of Thurgau announces that from October 23, 2020 onwards, it is obligatory to wear a protective face mask at public and private events with 30 or more persons. Exceptions to this rule apply to children up to the age of 12 years, for persons who can prove that they cannot wear a mask for medical, reasons, for personnel, if they are protected by a physical barrier (e.g. plexiglass), as well as for performers (artists, sportsmen and sportswomen, etc.). The consumption of food and beverages is permitted exclusively in the seating areas provided for this purpose.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On December 9, 2020 the Swiss Canton Saint Gallen announced that residents of retirement facilities are still allowed to welcome to visitors per day but it is only allowed to meet in the lobby, foyer or cafeteria, meetings in private rooms are prohibited. This measure should relieve the compliance of the social distancing restrictions and the employees of the facilities.
